H0.text: Decreases is the atmospheric pressure as altitude increases.

H1.text: Increase is the change in atmospheric pressure that occurs as altitude increases.

H2.text: Stays the same is the correct description of atmospheric pressure when altitude increases.

H3.text: Depends on other factors is the answer to whether atmospheric pressure increases or decreases as altitude increases.

A4.text: As altitude increases, atmospheric pressure decreases.

A5.text: Temperature and humidity also affect the atmospheric pressure. Pressure is proportional to temperature and inversely related to humidity, and both of these are necessary to compute an accurate figure.

A6.text: Test showing a can being crushed after boiling water inside it, then moving it into a tub of ice-cold water.

A7.text: The barometric formula is a formula used to model how the air pressure (or air density) changes with altitude.

A8.text: Assuming constant temperature, integrating gives the second barometric formula: P = P0 e^{-Mgz/R*T}.
